Posts.Content: There is a lot of controversy about soy and bc. When I did my research on it, what I understood it to say was that soy actually jumps in and takes a place on an estrogen receptor, which blocks the estrogen from grabbing that place. That is a good thing. Some docs say yay and some say nay. Look into it and understand what they are saying about soy's estrogen blocking effects. Me...I am on the side that says its okay. ----------------------------------------------- Where is the cure??? www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Soy Harmful For Breast Cancer?

Posts.Content: Sorry if this message triplicates. I'm having a hard time getting it posted.   For those of you interested in DIEP breast reconstruction, here is a good site for information: diepbreastreconstruction dot org I had bilateral and absolutely love my breasts. I continually spead the word because so many women still do not know that they have this option. Many blessings. cc4cure truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Breast Reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Rosie, if you are looking for docs in California, who do Diep, there are a few in the south and then there is Dr. Kind, in the north. If you go to www.diepbreastreconstruction.org/forum, there are DIEP doctors on that site who will answer your questions about DIEP. Three are from California. There is also discussion about DIEP. CC
Posts.Title: Diep Procedure in Atlanta?

Posts.Content: This article came out nearly a year ago. I posted the link in several forums for women who had the same question as you. Hope it helps. http://www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/news/news2. 28.05.asp CC4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org/tips.htm
Posts.Title: Moms Cancer

Posts.Content: So sorry you are having this scare. Could the scaly bruise be the possible cause of the itching? Possibly a fungal infection or ringworm? IBC tends to grow and spread very fast, with symptoms of red, itchy, hot orange peel skin. Has the look of the scaly bruise changed any since you discovered it?  It is really wise to see your doc about it. He or she will more than likely take a skin sample for pathology. Sending best wishes that everything turns out well for you.  CC
Posts.Title: Happy New Year? maybe not

Posts.Content: No one can really ever say how long remission will last. I am assuming that is why your doc won't make a committment. I have known of women who have been in remission for years. I have also read of women who have gone on to live their lives with bone cancer for more than 10 years. It's all a crap shoot. Some women make it a very long time and others do not. Try to do things to help yourself. Complex carbs are very good for you, but if you eat a lot of simple carbs...cut them out of your diet. You can read a little about that here: www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org/eating.htm One thing to remember is that as long as cancer is stable, it will not kill you. That is why docs are so happy if they can even get their patients to stabilize. A person can live with a cancerous tumor in their body, forever...as long as it does not grow and spread. The metastasis, whereby it spreads and destroys tissue is what is toxic to the body and what kills. Wishing you the best. C
Posts.Title: in Remission

Posts.Content: Here is a post from bcsisters.org "The difference with receptor negative and receptor positive is that the positives are helped more with the inhibitors, such as Aromatase and Tamoxifen, etc, because their cancers are hormone driven; whereas the negatives are helped more by chemo, as we have a more agressive cancer, which is chemo's purpose. With the negatives, the greater chance for recurrence is the few years after the initial diagnosis, with much less chance for recurrence after those first few years of being cancer free. That, to me, is good news. With positives, the chance for recurrence does not diminish as greatly, over the years, due to the fact that their cancer is hormone driven. The reason why you may read that having negative receptors is bad is only because after our initial treatment, there is nothing else that can be done for us. There are no inhibitors we can take. I believe they are working on a vaccine for us negatives, which is now in clinical trials."
Posts.Title: What About us Women Who Are Not Hormone Positive????

Posts.Content: I really couldn't say, Patti. It's such a personal decision. Negative cancers are highly aggressive, however. You made a choice that you felt was right for you. Only time would be able to let you know if that was a mistake, or not. I wish you well. cc4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: What About us Women Who Are Not Hormone Positive????

Posts.Content: I had bilateral skin-sparing mastectomies, with DIEP reconstruction. I think you've made a wise choice. My breasts look so normal that no one could even tell that they aren't the originals...unless I told them. I am a great advocate of DIEP and pass on the word wherever I can. More women need to know this surgery exist and that they have other options that are less invasive than losing their muscle. Hope all goes well for you. CC--- www(dot)diepbreastreconstruction(dot)org
Posts.Title: diep surgery

Posts.Content: On 10/8/2007 tam92407 wrote: Prior to my bilateral mast next week, I have to have blue dye injected for the sentinel node biopsy.  I have heard this dye is very painful.  Anyone know for sure?   Yes, I had this done. It really stings, but you can do it...without tears. Just take a deep breath and do the "grunt and bear it" technique, and you will do fine. The doc does about 5 needle sticks. One other thing...your urine may be blue for a few hours or so...maybe even a day, after the injection, so don't be afraid. My best to you. Where is the cure??? truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Blue Dye

Posts.Content: I had rads on one side. I had diep in February, 2004 and have had no problems, other than minor areas of necrosis, which come with most flap surgeries. The difference between delayed recon, with diep, and immediate recon, with diep, is that with delayed recon the breast will look good, if you have the correct Plastic Surgeon, but the shape has to be created, from scratch, instead of being natural, as with immediate recon, post mastectomy. I hope this is not too confusing. You can find some info on diep at: www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org/diep.htm
Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: I had skin-sparing, bilateral mastectomies, prophylactic on the left. They did the diep at the same time. I initially had a lumpectomy, but the doc didn't get clean margins. My cancer was so bad and so aggressive that the doc sent me straight to chemo, telling me that I didn't have time for mastectomy, right then. I had to get chemo right away. Anyway, once I was done with chemo, my onc sent me for rads, even though I was having mastectomies. I told the rad onc that I was having mastectomies. He told me it was best to have the rads because I didn't want the bc coming back in the skin. So, I had 33 rads. I then had to wait at least 6 months ( I waited 7) before I could have my dieps. After 7 months, I had the surgery and now I have breast that are so normal looking and feeling that I never even missed my other breasts. No one would even know that I had mastectomies, unless I told them. Necrosis is a piece of the fat that dies. It gets hard and feels like a lump. I had 4 areas of necrosis...three in the radiated breast and one in the non-cancerous breast. Many times they dissappear on their own, but your doc can also go in at the stage 2 revsion and break it up so that it dissolves better. One of mine dissolved. Just waiting for the others to dissolve. It can take a long time. Yes, I did have axillary dissection, along with snb, when I had my lumpectomy. I had 17 nodes removed. Three were positive. I never had any problem with lymphedma. I have never heard of any woman getting lympedema after diep. Not saying it isn't true, I just have never heard of one case. Basically, the necrosis, as it relates to diep, is a section of the transferred fat that dies due to it not having enough blood reaching it. It is best to have both sides done at the same time, for a few reasons: 1. One surgery, which means that you only have to go under anesthesia the one time. 2. One recovery. You get it over all at once, instead of being down, twice. 3. They will be able to better match your breasts and make them symmetrical, if done at the same time....etc. I also lived alone when I had my surgery (now caregiver to my elderly mom). It is so doable. I know that we are all different and what is easy for one person is not as easy for another. I took only one pain pill in the hosipital (5 days). I was out walking on day 8, was at Harrah's on day 9 and I shopped all day on day 10. I took a few of the pain pills after I was out of the hospital. Just a few. I was able to shower and wash my hair on day three. I never needed any help getting out of the bed or doing anything for myself. I couldn't reach the top cabinet shelves, however. I never had any surgical pain in my breast. I had a lot of discomfort in my tummy, but I can't call it pain. Out of all of the recons available, diep has the less pain and less complications than the others. Go over to www.nolasociety.org/forum and view some of the posts. The forum is for women interested in, having or had diep or gap reconstructions. It is a little slow, so you may wait a bit for a response, but it is growing, as it is new. Maybe you can read some info there that will help you.
Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: Correct. No blood pressure, no blood draws, etc should be taken from the arm where you had axillary dissection. I think you read too much between the lines. Yes, I did have someone with me, but what I stated was that I did not need anyone to help me. I had someone with me but I could have very well traveled alone and gotten along very well. Some people can do that just fine, others really need to rely on someone. The absolutely only thing I had help with was the limo driver lifting my suitcase out of the trunk of the car. I tugged it, as my daughter had her own bags to tug. When my daughter and I went shopping, I carried bags. Heavy ones. We had shopped so much that I had to help get the bags back to McFarland. Basically, I had company. I did not need to rely on anyone for help. So, there was not much difference, at all. I basically "hoofed" on my own. If you have the correct drain belt, drains are a nusiance, but not so great of a problem. I think it all depends on how one views situations. If you tell yourself they will be a problem...then they will be. With a drain belt, you put place the tubes through the loops and move on. When you take a shower, tie a terry cloth robe belt around your neck and pin the drains to it and your hands are free. Wring the belt, hang it over the rod to dry, until the next shower. Some women come home with 0 to 2 drains. I had one. After three weeks, I removed it myself. You have one drain at the bottom of each breast and one drain on each side of the pubic area. I faxed them a copy of my docs recommendations for mastectomy and my history. I took with me only the copy of my mammo's. 48 pounds overweight is but a mere issue, compared to some of the heavier women that have this surgery. Go the the "Before & After" section of this site, to see photos: www.breastcenter.com. You really do not want to lose weight, as the tissue from your tummy will lose and gain weight just as it did on the tummy. You want to go into surgery as close to your normal weight as possible. If you are 48 pounds overweight, that is fine, as long as you are healthy and do not smoke. If you do smoke, you will need to stop before and after the surgery. Not sure why you are feeling vain to consider this surgery. You want to feel whole. That is how God made you and you have the right to be whole again. No vainity here. If your leg was amputated, would you feel vain to want your leg back, if that were possible? If your ear was amputated, would it mean you were vain to want your ear back? Your breast is another part of your body. Would a man be considered vain if his "you know what" was amputated he he had the opportunity to have it reconstructed? I think not. I wish you the best. cc4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: I had my surgery in NOLA with Drs Sullivan and DellaCroce. I am going to point you to a great website that has a lot of women who go through Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomies. There will be many women there to help you and who have been through or are going through what you are going through: www.facingyourrisk.org

Posts.Content: No, I didn't have it. I am tripple negative. My cancer is not hormone driven and thus it will not work for me. cc4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org

Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, we will never know we are safe until there is a cure. Cancer is a sneaky b*%#ard and just when you think you got it beat is when it rears it's ugly head. Just tell your friend to always be in tune to her body and to investigate what falls outside of normal. It is a long road we travel. cc4cure truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: is my friend cancer free?

Posts.Content: I am triple negative, as well. We may not have any other treatments available to us after chemo, but what we do have going for us is that the farther out from diagnosos we get, the less chance we have for recurrence. They say that after the first two years, which is the most common chance of recurrence for us, the recurrence rate diminishes greatly. After you get to five years, it is said that we are once again like the normal population. Women with positive receptors do not get this chance. They are at strong risk for recurrence for the rest of their lives. We are at less risk for recurrence the farther out we get. Some women are so fearful of being triple negative...I was happy to be - - -. When my breast surgeon told me I was triple negative, I went "Yesssss!" and he looked at me like I was crazy. I did not want any part of those meds that the positive receptor women have to take. Many of them have horrific side effect for all of the years they have to take it. They have to be screened closely for uterine cancer, if they are on Tamoxifen. I am sorry I got BC, but I feel I lucked out with the bc that I got...bad report and all. I am 5 years and two months out from diagnosis and I have not had a recurrence...knock on wood. I had a pretty bad pathology, large tumor, positive nodes, lymphatic and vessel invasion, micro focal spread, triple negative, etc, etc. I thank God everyday for his blessings. I wish the same for you. PS>>> I hope I haven't already posted in this thread. There are so many, I can't remember which ones I've visited. Sorry for any repetition cc4cure truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: triple negative br. cancer

Posts.Content: So sorry. It should be www.facingourrisk.org. You have a great New Year, too! cc4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org

Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: I traveled by plane from California to New Orleans to have my surgery. I could have managed it by myself, because the plastic surgeon I went to had a limo pick me up at the airport and take me back. The driver lifted my luggage, though my daughter was there for the return. My PS took great care of me. If daughter wasn't there, I would have tipped a handler to do it for me. My daughter flew into New Orleans on day 7, thinking I would need taken care of. My sis was there with me for the first week, but she left on the morning of the day I was discharged, so she wasn't there if I needed anything, but was there for company while I was in the hospital. I was discharged on Sunday and my daughter arrived on Tuesday, at midnight, so I was there, alone, for going into 3 days. I never needed help with anything at all. The nurses kept calling me a "phenomenon". When my daughter arrived, she called me to let me know she was a couple of minutes away. I was staying at McFarland Inn, which was a building attached to the hospital. Everything closes up after a certain hour and the only entrance is through the emergency room. I went down there to meet her. She said she was so shocked when she saw me because she was expecting a sick looking mom, bent over and in pain and what she saw was a mom standing straight, smiling. Since Katrina, the docs have relocated. Still in Louisiana, but just not in New Orleans. I think they are in Meterie (sp?). No...not saying rads have influence on diep. It would be the same no matter what recon you have, probably except the pedicle tram...which you really do not want to think about...believe me. Women can get necrosis, without surgery, just by getting hit in the breast. I also had an area of necrosis in the non-radiated breast. It just so happened that I had 3 areas in the radiated breast and one in the other. It could have been vice versa. Never think it is too late. Women have recons even when they have find out that they have mets. You have to do what makes you feel good and whole...no matter what. I, too, was very lucky in not having mets. I do so much research and take supps to help keep it at bay. Docs have expected me to recur before now, but so far so good. I am nearly 3.5 years out from diagnosis. If I were you, I would certainly ask my PS about the issue with your having nodes removed from both axillaries and if that would cause concern. Believe me, by the time you leave, you won't be at a stage where you will pass out at the airport. You will feel quite well, with some soreness in the abdomen. You will be able to walk, sit, stand, without much effort. I was in New Orleans for 13 days. The norm is about 10, when you travel. I stayed the extra 3 days on my own. I had gone there not knowing what to expect and did not want to come home til I knew I would be fine, so I booked 13 days. I actually felt well enough to come home by day 6 or 7. cc4cure (aka Cindy) www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Eligibility & Prerequisites For Diep

Posts.Content: I had lumpectomy, with subsequent bilateral mastectomies, prophylactic on the left. My cancer was extremely aggressive. It grew from the size of the dime, when I found it, to almost 5cm's by the time I had surgery. I had 4 AC and 4 Taxotere, plus 33 rads. Docs were expecting me to recur by now, as I had extensive angiolymphatic invasion and multi focal spread. I did tons of research and after my treatments, I started taking a lot of supplements, to include IP6, with inositol hexaphosphate. I also take Turmeric, quercetin and everything I could find that was anti-tumor, to include, enzymes and aspirin a few times per week. What I found through my research is that researchers believe there is a connection between inflammation in the body and cancer, as everywhere they find cancer, they find inflammation. So I take a lot of supps that are natural anti-inflammatories, as well as anti-tumor. So far, so good. cc4cure www.truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: Post Surgery Treatment Options

Posts.Content: On 9/28/2007 warriorgirl wrote: My mother is looking for others like her, who have had hearing problems after her chemo. Her message is below. thank you in advance,  " I had adriamycin and cytoxan for 4 treatments.  Then I had 12 treatments of herceptin and taxol.  This was followed by a triple dose of herceptin at 3weeks interval.  After that I had a hearing loss, ringing in my ears and amplified background noise.   Is there anyone who has had hearing problems after receiving these drugs.  Thank you for responding"  Email    --Message edited by CancerCompass staff. For personal protection, email address removed. Consider private reply. Please review CancerCompass Member Guidelines at http://www.cancercompass.com/common/guidelines.html-- I STILL have ringing in my ears...4 years after finishing chemo. I was also left with headaches (daily) and other stuff. In May, I lost all hearing in my right ear. It came back gradually over 4 days. People sounded like they were talking like chipmunks, as the hearing was coming back. I look at all of the stuff I was dealt, with having the chemo, but had I not had it, I would not have survived. I know I have been made old before my time...but I am so thankful to be alive. Where is the cure??? truefacesofbreastcancer.org
Posts.Title: strange side effects
